publicAdvisory.title: Hazards due to wildfire damage
publicAdvisory.description:
There are significant risks associated with entering areas that have been burnt over by the 2021 wildfires.

Potential risks could include:

  • danger trees and overhead hazards – the integrity of trees whose trunks, roots or branches have been damaged by wildfire is unreliable
  • terrain instability resulting in landslides and falling or shifting debris and rock
  • amplified runoff after rainfall or snowmelt which could result in a rapid increase of water course depth and flow rates or flooding conditions
  • ash pits – may be deep and difficult to see
  • respiratory effects caused by breathing soot and charcoal for extended periods of time

Post-wildfire hazards may last for several years or longer after a wildfire and may be triggered at any time with little or no warning.

We are asking public to refrain from entering this sensitive area while it recovers from the traumatic 2021 wildfire season.

publicAdvisory.title: Viewing salmon during spawning season
publicAdvisory.description:
BC Parks is eagerly anticipating the return of the Kokanee salmon to the spawning channel at Kokanee Creek Park. The park has an elevated boardwalk to allow visitors to view the salmon in the spawning channel. BC Parks would like to remind visitors that during the spawning period, bears are also frequent visitors to the channel to feed on the salmon. To protect both people and bears the spawning channel viewing areas have special regulations in place during the salmon run.

These restrictions will come into effect when the Kokanee spawning is occurring in the channel, approximately August 15th to September 30th and will include:

  • Dogs will not be permitted on the boardwalk or the trails adjacent to the spawning channel.
  • Bicycles must be walked across the boardwalk and along the trails adjacent to the spawning channel.
  • The portion of the spawning channel downstream of the viewing platform will be closed to the public during the period that bears are utilizing it for feeding. This closure will include the trails behind the Nature Center.

Cow Parsnip and Giant Hogweed
publicAdvisory.description:
Cow Parsnip is a native plant and is part of healthy and diverse ecosystems in BC Parks. It is also a culturally important plant for many local First Nations. Cow Parsnip can sometimes be confused with the very toxic and invasive plant Giant Hogweed. BC Parks would like you to advise visitors that Cow Parsnip can also cause people’s skin to react to sunlight if they come in contact with it, although much less severely than for Giant Hogweed. Cow Parsnip can be located throughout the park and along trails and campsite edges. BC Parks encourages visitors to take necessary steps to avoid coming in contact with the plant and to stay on designated trails and sites.

  • 375 linear metre trail surfacing (2m width, 3/8” high fines cart path mix – accessible surface)
  • 80 linear metre elevated boardwalk/railings (<5% grade-accessible, screw pile footings – low environmental impact)

publicAdvisory.title: Hazards due to wildfire damage
publicAdvisory.description:
There are significant risks associated with entering areas that have been burnt over by the 2017 wildfires.

Potential risks could include:

  • danger trees and overhead hazards – the integrity of trees whose trunks, roots or branches have been damaged by wildfire is unreliable
  • terrain instability resulting in landslides and falling or shifting debris and rock
  • amplified runoff after rainfall or snowmelt which could result in a rapid increase of water course depth and flow rates or flooding conditions
  • ash pits – may be deep and difficult to see
  • respiratory effects caused by breathing soot and charcoal for extended periods of time

publicAdvisory.title: Help protect breeding Western Toads
publicAdvisory.description:

publicAdvisory.title: White-Nosed Syndrome
publicAdvisory.description:
White-nose Syndrome is a fungal disease that has been linked to the mass die-off of hibernating bats in Eastern North America – it poses a significant threat to bats of the west and British Columbia. There is evidence that humans have accelerated the spread through entering caves with contaminated clothing, gear or equipment. To help prevent WNS from taking hold in B.C., the Province is making investments in bat conservation projects.

To ensure the protection of bats and their habitat in this park, BC Parks strongly advises that personal caving gear that has been used anywhere east of the Rockies not be used in B.C. Also, before entering caves in B.C, cavers and visitors should consult the provincial WNS website, which includes a link to a Decontamination Protocol for Mines and Caves.

  • Learn more about white-nose syndrome

publicAdvisory.title: New Bio-Cleaning Station
publicAdvisory.description:
Protecting bats from White-Nose Syndrome at Horne Lake Caves.

BC Parks installed a bio-cleaning station at Horne Lake Caves Provincial Park to ensure visitors are not entering caves with contaminated clothing, gear or equipment, which researchers believe can carry the fungus causing White-Nose Syndrome. Funded through proceeds from the BC Parks Licence Plate Program, the bio-cleaning station helps remove fungal spores that could cause the disease. Before entering the caves, visitors walk along an artificial turf mat to scrub fungal spores off their shoes, and then step into a diluted detergent and water solution, followed by a water rinse. The same process is applied when leaving. Please watch the video to learn more about the bio-cleaning station at Horne Lake Caves Park.

The C7îstkteñ Winter House Project honours the unique and deeply meaningful Indigenous culture and long occupation history of this area. Indigenous use at this site stretches back millennia. Caution: be advised that there are significant risks associated with entering areas that have been burnt over by the 2017 wildfires. Potential risks could include:

  • danger trees and overhead hazards – the integrity of trees whose trunks, roots or branches have been damaged by wildfire is unreliable
  • terrain instability resulting in landslides and falling or shifting debris and rock
  • amplified runoff after rainfall or snowmelt which could result in a rapid increase of water course depth and flow rates or flooding conditions
  • ash pits – may be deep and difficult to see
  • respiratory effects caused by breathing soot and charcoal for extended periods of time

Post-wildfire hazards may last for several years or longer after a wildfire and may be triggered at any time with little or no warning.

The Keith Flavelle Hut (Keith’s Hut) is outside the closure area, however, the Hut remains closed due to PHO COVID-19 restrictions.

Signage has been posted at the trailheads and on the conservancy website.

BC Parks will be conducting a further assessment of the closure area in 2021.

publicAdvisory.title: Trail and recreational access closures this fall

Trail and recreational access closures this fall

Please be advised that BC Parks will be conducting three fuel management projects in West Arm Park this fall (September to December). To ensure public safety during these treatments, there will be trail closures and recreational access closures associated with all three projects.

  1. 12.7 hectare hand treatment 1km up Svoboda Road in the vicinity of Short Svoboda, Frog Jam, Squeeler, and Toe Jam Trails. Expect trail closures from September 8th until late November or early December. Please also see trail information on the Nelson Cycling Club’s Facebook page.
  2. 12.7 hectare hand treatment along Lasca Road. There will be no recreational access beyond the gate as of September 1st until late November or early December.
  3. 15.4 hectare mechanical treatment at the end of Lasca Road. There will be no recreational access beyond the gate as of September 1st until late November or early December.

Please obey all informational signage posted on site and please check this website often for the latest updates.

For more information please call 250 489-9211.

BC Parks is eagerly anticipating the return of the Kokanee salmon to the spawning channel at Kokanee Creek Park. The park has an elevated boardwalk to allow visitors to view the salmon in the spawning channel. BC Parks would like to remind visitors that during the spawning period, bears are also frequent visitors to the channel to feed on the salmon. To protect both people and bears, the spawning channel viewing areas have special regulations in place during the salmon run.

These restrictions will come into effect when the Kokanee spawning is occurring in the channel, from August 14th to October 7th, 2020 and will include:

  1. Dogs will not be permitted on the boardwalk or the trails adjacent to the spawning channel.
  2. Bicycles must be walked across the boardwalk and along the trails adjacent to the spawning channel.
  3. The portion of the spawning channel downstream of the viewing platform will be closed to the public during the period that bears are utilizing it for feeding. This closure will include the trails behind the Nature Center.
  4. Please respect the new covid-19 guidelines and traffic flow signs for the Spawning Channel trails. Wearing a mask is encouraged.

publicAdvisory.title: Park Opening Announcement
publicAdvisory.description:
BC Parks is very pleased to announce jointly with Xeni Gwet’in First Nation that Ts’il?os Provincial Park is open for both day-use and overnight camping, including Nu Chugh Beniz & Gwe Da Ts’ih campgrounds.

BC Parks has continued to keep the health and wellbeing of our visitors, staff, park operators, and local communities as our top priority by implementing COVID-19 safety protocols and respecting continued PHO guidelines around physical distancing,

The BC Parks Guide to Camping During COVID-19 is an excellent resource to help you understand what to expect when you arrive at the campgrounds. The guide outlines how to prepare, set up, and stay safe while visiting BC Parks.

All visitors to Ts’il?os Park are asked to be fully self-contained and to have no contact with local community members in the Nemiah Valley in order to limit the chance of spreading the COVID-19 virus. The gas station, tire repair and convenience store are closed to non-residents. Visitors are reminded to check www.xenigwetin.net for updates on access to Title Lands.

We appreciate your ongoing cooperation as we work to keep our staff, park operators, local communities, and visitors safe.

publicAdvisory.title: Mahood Lake Group Site closed until further notice
publicAdvisory.description: Due to extreme flooding conditions the group site, as well as campsites 33 and 34 at Mahood Lake campground is unusable at this time.  Reservation holders for the sites will be notified and refunded their fees for camping.  BC Parks will continue to monitor the water situation and update this webpage as conditions improve.

publicAdvisory.title: Train line adjacent to park
publicAdvisory.description: Park visitors should be aware of a train line which runs alongside the park. Trains can run during the early hours of the morning which can cause some noise disruption within the park.

publicAdvisory.title: Prevent raccoons from becoming food conditioned
publicAdvisory.description: Secure all your belongings and do not feed the raccoons.  This [park-type] has an abundant raccoon population that thrives on park visitor’s food, garbage and other scented items.

publicAdvisory.title: Construction noise
publicAdvisory.description: Park visitors should be aware of an excavation project currently underway across from the park between the hours of 7am - 4pm. Minor noise and vibration disruption may occur during this time. Thanks!

publicAdvisory.title: BC Parks warns visitors to use extra caution due to high water in the Thompson River
publicAdvisory.description: With all the campsites in this popular park being located along the Thompson River, and the extreme high water flows currently being experienced, BC Parks is warning our visitors to use extra caution. Extreme caution, especially with children or pets, should be exercised at this time. In some locations the river is flowing at less than a metre from the backside of campsites.

publicAdvisory.title: Notice of Temporary Closure

Please exercise caution when accessing the area via the western entry, as vehicle movement will be restricted. Please observe all signage. Thank you for your cooperation.

publicAdvisory.title: Flooding on the Bowron Lake Canoe Circuit
publicAdvisory.description: There is currently significant flooding on the Bowron Lake Canoe Circuit and visitors should be aware that some camping areas may not currently be accessible. Canoers should be prepared to canoe an extended distance should their preferred area be experiencing flooding. The east side of the circuit remains closed until at least July 20, inclusive, with the possibility that a closure extension may be required.

publicAdvisory.title: Please be aware of poor road conditions on industrial roads required to access this park
publicAdvisory.description:

publicAdvisory.title: The historic Peace Arch monument will be refurbished in the summer of 2020
publicAdvisory.description: The work is expected to take place from July 16th to September. The work will include vapour blasting, priming, repainting, restoring inscriptions, restoring ornamental gates, and restoring the commemorative plaques. Please note the arch may not be visible during this time due to the need to wrap the structure to contain removed paint and protect the work.

There is no guarantee that Tweedsmuir South Park will remain open and we appreciate the public’s cooperation to stay within their local communities during these challenging times as per the Provincial Health Officer directives.

The Clearwater River Road (the gravel road along the west side of the Clearwater River, used primarily by fishers and kayakers) is closed beyond the Kettle at 9km, again due to water damage. Updates will be provided as conditions change.

New day-use reservation system
publicAdvisory.description:
As of July 27th, a new day-use reservation system is in effect for day-use access to the Berg Lake Trail.

Your day-use reservation is free of charge. Passes are available starting at 6AM for a same day visit. You will need your pass before arriving at the checkpoint along Kinney Lake Road.

You can obtain a pass on the Discover Camping website. To access the reservation site, we recommend you do this before heading out on your trip. If you are already en route, wifi can be found at the Mount Robson Visitor Centre, or the Mount Terry Fox Highway rest area.

Please note: Passes do not guarantee a parking spot. Visitors should plan accordingly.

publicAdvisory.title: Public access to the column features is not permitted
publicAdvisory.description: Keremeos Columns Park does not contain the geological features that were intended to be protected at the time of establishment in the early 1930s. The column features are fully contained on private land. At this time, public access to the column features is not permitted. Viewing of the column features must be done so by using valley bottom vantage points that do not involve encroachment or access onto private land.
